To Illustrate this, Italians say that Pella always pays the most
careful and respectful attention during the speeches of Socialist
Deputy Riocardo Lombardi* often regarded as the most skillful and
knowledgeable opponent of the Pella financial policies*
A whole host of homely Pella sayings somewhat reminiscent of Poor
Richard's Almanac have circulated as the result of his years as the
anti-inflationary budget minister. This is said to be one of his own
favorites; ''It is true that when prices go up* then wages must go up*
too. But let us remember that while the prices take the ©levator* wages
climb up the stairs on foot.'*
By way of illustrating the Italian tendency to optimism to
American Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce* Pella pointed to a half-empty
pack of cigarettes on the table.
"The pessimist*H Pella explained* "will say* I have only ten left;
but the optimist will say* I still have ten left. This is our optimism.**
In spite of all the Information available about him and all these
supposedly revealing anecdotes* Pella remains something of a political
mystery man.
As I say* this is due partly to the fact that as budget minister
he behaved in a conciliatory, non-politleal manner. It is also due to
the fact that to date as prime minister he has shied away from decisions
on most controversial Italian political questions.
His official viewpoints are well known. He has reiterated them
since becoming premier* But how hard he would fight for any tiling except
the "defense of the Lira" policy few Italian politicians profess to know.
